data.title: Famous People Born in 1889
data.meta_description: Celebrate the birthdays of 248 famous people, historical figures and celebrities born in 1889 like Adolf Hitler, Charlie Chaplin and António de Oliveira Salazar.
data.text:
Birthdays 1 - 200 of 248

Alexander Smallens, Russian-born American conductor, born in St Petersburg, Russia (d. 1972)

Jan 1 Charles Bickford, American actor (Dynamite, The Virginian), born in Cambridge, Massachusetts (d. 1967)

Jan 1 Tadeusz Jarecki, Polish composer and conductor, born in Lemberg, Austria-Hungary (d. 1955)

Jan 1 Tom Dugan, Irish actor (Circus Clown, Drag, Skyway), born in Dublin, Ireland (d. 1955)

Walter Baldwin, American actor (The Best Years of Our Lives, The Long, Long Trailer), born in Lima, Ohio (d. 1977)

Nicholas Soussanin, Russian-American actor (Last Command, Captain Fury), born in Yalta part of modern day Crimea, Taurida Governorate, Russian Empire (d. 1975)

Albert van Dalsum, Dutch actor and director (Wilton's Zoo; Little Rascal), born in Nieuwer-Amstel, Noord-Holland, Netherlands (d. 1971)

Alan Mara Bateman, Canadian geologist (Yale professor), born in Kingston, Canada (d. 1971)

Calvin Bridges, American geneticist (d. 1938)

Vincenzo Davico, Italian composer, born in Monaco (d. 1969)

Louis Santop, American Baseball HOF catcher (5 x NgL East All-Star; Hilldale Athletic Club), born in Tyler, Texas (d. 1942)

Sophie Taeuber-Arp, Swiss painter, sculptor and dancer, born in Davos, Switzerland (d. 1943)

Allan Haines Loughead, American aviation executive (d. 1969)

Pitirim Sorokin, Russian-American sociologist (Social mobility), born in Turya, Russia (d. 1968)

Henri Pélissier, French cyclist (Tour de France 1923), born in Paris, France (d. 1935)

Franklin Pangborn, American actor (My Best Gal, Hats Off, Easy Living), born in Newark, New Jersey (d. 1958)

Jan 23 Prosper Arents, Belgium librarian and bibliographer (reconstructed Peter Paul Rubens library) (d. 1984)

Vladimir Shcherbachov, Soviet-Russian composer (Blokovskaya; The Thunderstorm), and professor (Leningrad Conservatory; Tbilisi Conservatory), born in Warsaw, Poland, Russian Empire (d. 1952)

Balthasar van der Pol, Dutch physicist (Comparison of Van der Pol), born in Utrecht, Netherlands (d. 1959)

Francisco Santiago, Filipino pianist, composer (Taga-ilog Symphony), conductor, and pedagogue, born in Santa Maria, Bulacan, Philippines (d. 1947)

Jan 29 Rudolf Mauersberger, German choral conductor and composer (Dresdner Requiem), born in Mauersberg, Kingdom of Saxony, German Empire (d. 1971)

Jaishankar Prasad, Hindi poet, dramatist and novelist, born in Varanasi, India (d. 1937)

Frank Foster, English cricket all-rounder (11 Tests, 3 x 50, 45 wickets, BB 6/91; Warwickshire CCC), born in Birmingham, England (d. 1958)

Gertrude Caton-Thompson, British archaeologist (Zimbabwe, So Arabia), born in London, England (d. 1985)

Carl Theodor Dreyer, Danish director (Passion of Jeanne d'arc), born in Copenhagen, Denmark (d. 1968)

Feb 3 Risto Ryti, Finnish politician (Prime Minister of Finland 1939-41, President of Finland 1940-44), born in Huittinen, Finland (d. 1956)

Walter Catlett, American actor (Climax, Front Page, Tale of 2 Cities), born in San Francisco, California (d. 1960)

E H (Patsy) Hendren, English cricket batsman (51 Tests, 7 x 100s, HS 205no; 57,611 1st-class runs, 3rd-best ever; Middlesex CCC), born in Turnham Green, England (d. 1962)

Feb 5 Ernest Tyldesley, English cricket batsman (14 Tests, 3 x 100, 6 x 50, HS 138; Lancashire CCC), born in Worsley, England (d. 1962)

Feb 5 Ioan Dumitru Chirescu, Romanian composer and conductor, born in Cernavodă, Romainia (d. 1980)

Karel Wellens, Flemish painter, born in Lummen, Belgium (d. 1958)

Feb 6 Siegfried Kracauer, German writer, born in Frankfurt, Germany (d. 1966)

Harry Nyquist, Swedish-American physicist and electronic engineer who contributed to communication theory (Nyquist–Shannon sampling theorem; Nyquist rate), born in Nilsby, Värmland, Sweden (d. 1976)

Feb 7 Ludwig Winder, Austrian-Czech writer and journalist, born in Šafov, Moravia, Austria-Hungary (d. 1946)

Larry Semon, American silent film actor, director, producer, and screenwriter (The Wizard of Oz (1925)), born in West Point, Mississippi (d. 1928) [Note: many sources erroneously cite July 16]

Howard Spring, Welsh writer and critic (O Absalom), born in Cardiff, Wales (d. 1965)

Vladimir Mikhaylovich Deshevov, Russian-Soviet composer (Ice and Steel), born in St. Petersburg, Russia (d. 1955)

H[aroldson] L Hunt, Texas oil tycoon (East Texas Oil Field), born near Ramsey, Illinois (d. 1974)

George Mogridge, American baseball pitcher (World Series 1924 Washington Senators; no-hitter 1917 NY Yankees), born in Rochester, New York (d. 1962)

Feb 18 Sybold van Ravesteyn, Dutch architect (Blijdorp, CS Rotterdam, Utrecht), born in Rotterdam, Netherlands (d. 1983)

Levko Revutsky, Ukrainian composer, music editor and pedagogue, born in Irzhavets, Ukraine, Russian Empire (d. 1977)

Felix Aylmer, British actor (Anastasia, Hamlet, Iron Duke, Macbeth, St Joan), born in Corsham, Wiltshire, England (d. 1979)

Olave Baden-Powell, English founder of the Girl Guide (d. 1977)

Feb 22 Robin G. Collingwood, English philosopher. historian ("The Principles of Art"; "The Idea of History") and archaeologist (Roman Britain), born in Cartmel Fell, England (d. 1943)

Frederik M. baron of Asbeck, Dutch lawyer and legal scholar (League of Nations), born in Den Helder, Netherlands (d. 1968)

Feb 23 Musidora [Jeanne Roques], French actress and director (Les vampires, Judex), born in Paris, France (d. 1957)

Victor Fleming

American film director (The Wizard of Oz; Gone With The Wind), born in Pasadena, California

Homer S. Ferguson, United States Senator (d. 1982)

Freddie Keppard, American jazz cornetist (Original Creole Orchestra), born in New Orleans, Louisiana (d. 1933)

Victor Sutherland, American actor (Captive City), born in Paducah, Kentucky (d. 1968)

Watsuji Tetsuro, Japanese philosopher (d. 1960)

Fritz Behrend, German composer, born in Berlin, Germany (d. 1972)

Oren E. Long, 10th Territorial Governor of Hawai'i (d. 1965)

Mar 4 Oscar Chisini, Italian mathematician (d. 1967)

Philip Guedalla, English barrister and historian, born in London, England (d. 1944)

Mar 12 Þórbergur Þórðarson, Icelandic author (d. 1974)

Reggie Walker, South African athlete (Olympic gold 100m 1908), born in Durban, South Africa (d. 1951)

Albert Hill, English athlete (Olympic gold 800m, 1500m 1920), born in London (d. 1969)

Howard Lindsay, American playwright, actor and director (State of the Union), born in Waterford, New York (d. 1968)

Warner Baxter

American actor (In Old Arizona, Cisco Kid), born in Columbus, Ohio

Grigoras Dinicu, Romanian violin virtuoso and composer, born in Bucharest, Kingdom of Romania (d. 1949)

Barry Macollum, Irish actor (The Trouble With Harry), born in Ireland (d. 1971)

Chilean poet (Nobel Prize for Literature, 1945), educator and diplomat, born in Vicuña, Chile

Nick LaRocca, American jazz coronetist and composer ("Tiger Rag"), born in New Orleans, Louisiana (d. 1961)

Herbert Yardley, American cryptologist, born in Worthington, Indiana (d. 1958)

Arnold J. Toynbee

English historian (A Study of History), born in London

Efim Bogoljubov, Russian-German chess player, born in Stanislavchyk, Tarashcha Uyezd, Kiev Governorate, Russian Empire (d. 1952)

Apr 14 James Stephenson, British actor (Letter, Espionage Agent, Nancy Drew), born in Selby, Yorkshire, England (d. 1941)

Apr 15 Thomas Hart Benton, American painter and muralist (Lonesome Road), born in Neosho, Missouri (d. 1975)

Charlie Chaplin

British actor and comedian (City Lights, Gold Rush), born in London, England

Jessie Street, Australian suffragette and aboriginal rights fighter, born in Ranchi, Bihar, Bengal Presidency, British Raj (d. 1970)

Apr 18 John Kilbane, American featherweight boxer and World Featherweight Champion (1912-23), born in Cleveland, Ohio (d. 1957)

Otto Georg Thierack, German jurist and politician (Reich Minister of Justice 1942-45), born in Wurzen, Kingdom of Saxony, German Empire (d. 1946)

Adolf Hitler

Austrian-born German dictator and Führer of Nazi Germany (1936-45), born in Gasthof zum Pommer, Braunau am Inn, Austria-Hungary

Albert Jean Amateau, Turkish-born businessman and social activist, born in Milas, Turkey (d. 1996)

Efrem Zimbalist Sr, Russian-American violinist, composer, and educator (Curtis Institute, 1928-68), born in Rostov on Don, Russia (d. 1985)

Apr 21 Paul Karrer, Swiss organic chemist (Nobel 1937), born in Moscow, Russia (d. 1971)

Ludwig Renn, German writer, born in Dresden, German Empire (d. 1979)

Charles Warrell, English schoolteacher and creator of the I-Spy books, born in Farmborough, Somerset (d. 1995)

Lyubov Popova, Russian avant-garde artist and painter, born in Ivanovskoe, Moscow (d. 1924)

Apr 24 Stafford Cripps, British Labour politician, born in London (d. 1952)

Charles Kelleway, Australian cricket all-rounder (26 Tests, 3 x 100s, 52 wickets, 24 catches), born in Lismore, Australia (d. 1944)

Ludwig Wittgenstein

Austrian English philosopher (Philosophical Investigations), born in Vienna, Austria-Hungary

António de Oliveira Salazar

Dictator of Portugal (1932-68) who founded and controlled the Estado Novo (New State), born in Vimieiro, Santa Comba Dão, Portugal

Bryant Washburn, American actor (Exposure, Millionaire Kid, Nabonga), born in Chicago, Illinois (d. 1963)

Apr 28 Karel Doorman, Dutch rear admiral (Java Sea), born in Utrecht, Netherlands (d. 1942)

Acario Cotapos, Chilean composer, born in Valdivia, Chile (d. 1969)

Beulah Bondi, American actress (It's a Wonderful Life), born in Chicago, Illinois (d. 1981)

Francis Spellman, American Bishop and Cardinal of Roman Catholic Church, born in Whitman, Massachusetts (d. 1967)

Herbie Taylor, South African cricket batsman and captain (42 Tests; 2,936 runs @ 40.77; 7 x 100s), born in Durban, South Africa (d. 1973)

Stanley Morison, British typographer, born in Wanstead, Essex (d. 1967)

Mae Murray, American silent screen actress, born in Portsmouth, Virginia (d. 1965)

Otto Frank, German born father of Anne Frank who saw her diaries published, born in Frankfurt (d. 1980)

Merie Earle [Ireland], American film and television character actress (The Waltons - "Maude Gormley"), born in Morrow, Ohio (d. 1984)

Bessie Abramowitz Hillman, Russian-American labor leader and founder of Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, born in Linoveh, Russia (d. 1970)

Joan Collette, Dutch graphic artist and painter (New Church, Delft), born in Delft, Netherlands (d. 1958)

Alfonso Reyes, Mexican writer (Simpatías y diferencias) and diplomat (Higenia Cruel), born in Monterrey, Mexico (d. 1959)

Gunnar Gunnarsson, Icelandic writer (The Church on the Mountain), born in Fljótsdalur, Iceland (d. 1975)

Felix Arndt, American organist, pianist, arranger, and composer ("Desecration Rag"; "Nola"), born in New York City (d. 1918) [1]

May 20 William Lawther, English union leader (National Union of Mine Workers 1939-54), born in Choppington, England (d. 1976)

Ernst Niekisch, German politician (d. 1967)

Creighton Hale, Irish actor (Gorilla Man, Way Down East), born in Cork, Ireland (d. 1965)

Gilardo Gilardi, Argentine composer, pianist and conductor (La leyenda del urutaú; Réquiem; Misa de Gloria), born in San Fernando, Argentina (d. 1963)

Igor Sikorsky

José Padilla, Spanish composer and pianist (La Violetera - City Lights; Ça c'est Paris - Moulin Rouge), born in Almería, Spain (d. 1960)

Henry Phillips, American businessman (Phillip's screw), born in Bolivar, Mississippi (d. 1958) [1]

Josef Hromádka, Czech Protestant theologist (Christian Peace Conference founder; Lenin Prize, 1957), born in Hodslavice, Moravia (d. 1969) [1]

Cliff Clark, American actor (Kid Glove Killer, Golden Hoofs, Vigilante Hideout), born in New York City (d. 1953)

Wesley Ruggles, American actor, producer and director (I'm No Angel, Arizona, Too Many Husbands), born in Los Angeles, California (d. 1972)

Victor van Straelen, Flemish biologist and paleontologist, born in Antwerp (d. 1964)

Paul Joostens, Belgian avant-garde artist, born in Antwerp, Belgium (d. 1960)

Enrico Celio, Swiss lawyer and President of Switzerland (1943), born in Ambrì, Switzerland (d. 1980)

John S. Paraskevopoulos, Greek-South African astronomer, born in Piraeus, Greece (d. 1951)

Ralph Craig, American athlete (Olympic gold 100/200m 1912), born in Detroit, Michigan (d. 1972)

Anna Akhmatova, Russian poet (Poem Without a Hero), born in Odessa, Ukraine (d. 1966)

Ethel Glenn Hier, American composer, born in Madisonville, Ohio (d. 1971)

Alfred Courtens, Belgian sculptor, born in Brussels, Belgium (d. 1967)

Willie Macfarlane, Scottish golfer (US Open 1925), born in Aberdeen, Scotland (d. 1961)

Jean Cocteau

Eugene Pallette, American actor (The Adventures of Robin Hood, The Mark of Zorro), born in Winfield, Kansas (d. 1954)

Léo Dandurand, American-Canadian hockey executive, born in Bourbonnais, Illinois (d. 1964)

Robert [Harriot] Barrat, American actor (Bad Lands, Go West, Distant Drums), born in New York City (d. 1970)

Alfred E. Green, American film director (Copacabana, The Jolson Story), born in Perris, California (d. 1960)

Marty Friedman, American Basketball Hall of Fame guard and coach (tied World C'ship series, New York Whirlwinds 1921), born in New York City (d. 1986)

Louise Mountbatten, Queen of Sweden as consort of King Gustaf VI Adolf, born at Schloss Heiligenberg, Seeheim-Jugenheim, Germany (d. 1965)

Ante Pavelić

Croatian leader of Nazi Germany puppet Independent State of Croatia, born in Bradina, Austria-Hungary

Marjorie Rambeau, American stage, silent and sound screen actress (Primrose Path; Torch Song), born in San Francisco, California (d. 1970)

Erle Stanley Gardner

American detective writer (Perry Mason), born in Malden, Massachusetts

Joe Dawson, American auto racer (Indianapolis 500 1912), born in Odon, Indiana (d. 1946)

John Charles Reith, 1st Baron Reith, British broadcasting executive and 1st director-general of BBC (1927-38), born in Stonehaven, Kincardineshire, Scotland (d. 1971)

Frederick Preston Search, American cellist, composer and conductor (Bridge Builders), born in Pueblo, Colorado (d. 1959)

Jul 22 James Whale, English film director (Frankenstein, Show Boat), born in Dudley, England (d. 1957)

Karl Otten, German Expressionist writer, born in Oberkrüchten (d. 1963)

Donald Foster, American actor (Hazel, Lord Love A Duck), born in Oil City, Pennsylvania (d. 1969)

Jack Ryder, Australian cricket all-rounder (20 Tests, 1,394 runs @ 51.62), born in Collingwood, Victoria (d. 1977)

(Cecil) Armstrong Gibbs, British composer, born in Great Baddow, Essex, England (d. 1960)

Aug 10 Charles Darrow, American businessman who modified and popularized Monopoly game, born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (d. 1967)
